I had been loſt without your art to help me.

sp.speaker: Eſte
sp.l: Love wo'not leave his votaries.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I hear my Mothers cough, I ha'finiſh'd
And you muſt act your part:

sp.speaker: Alſ.
sp.l: Come are you ready Daughter? the Coach ſtayes.

sp.speaker: Eſty.
sp.l: I attend

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Don Pedro will cure your cold before the morning.

div.stage: Enter Franciſco and takes away Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Teo.
sp.l: What duty Feliſarda ſhall we pay
To Heaven for this laſt care of us?
Let not thy eyes,
Although thy grief become 'em, be in love
With tears, I Propheſie a joy ſhall weigh
Down all our ſufferings, I ſee comfort break
Like day, whoſe forehead chears the world; if Don
Fernando love thee, he is a Gentleman,
Confirm'd in all that's honorable, and cannot
Forget whom his own vertue hath made choice
To ſhine upon.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Unleſs my Innocence,
Apt to believe a flattering tongue, ſee not
The Serpent couch, and hide his ſpeckled breſt
Among the flowers; but it were ſin to think
He can diſſemble, Father, and I know not,
Since I was firſt the object of his charity,
I find a pious gratitude diſperſe
Within my ſoul, and every thought of him
Engenders a warm ſigh within me, which
Like curles of holy Incenſe overtake
Each other in my boſom, and enlarge
With their Embrace his ſweet remembrance.

sp.speaker: Teo.
sp.l: Cheriſh
Thoſe thoughts, and where ſuch noble worth invites,
Be bold to call it love.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: It is too much
Ambition to hope he ſhould be juſt
To me, or keep his honor, when I look on
The pale complexion of my wants; and yet
Vnleſs he loves me dearly, I am loſt,
And if he have but mock'd me into faith,
He might as well have murdered me, for I
Shall have no heart to live, if his neglect
Deface what my affection printed there.

sp.speaker: Teo.
sp.l: There is no feare of his revolt, loſe not
His character. I muſt attend ſome buſineſs.
If Don Fernando viſit thee, preſerve
His fair opinion, and thou maiſt live
Above thy Uncles pitty.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Will you leave me?

sp.speaker: Teo.
sp.l: My ſtay ſhall not be long; the Garden will
With ſmiling flowres encourage thee to walk,
And raiſe thy drooping eyes, with hope to ſee

div.l: A ſpring like theirs, upon thee.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Why ſhould I
Give any entertainment to my fears?
Suſpicions are but like the ſhape of clouds,
And idle forms i'th' air, we make to fright us.
I will admit no jealous thought to wound
Fernandos truth, but with that chearfullneſs,
My own firſt clear intents to honour him
Can arm me with, expect to meet his faith
As noble as he promis'd—Ha! tis he.

div.l: My poor heart trembles like a timerous leaf,
Which the wind ſhakes upon his ſickly ſtalk,
And frights into a Palſey. Fer. Feliſarda!

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Shall I want fortitude to bid him welcome?
Sir, if you think there is a heart alive
That can be gratefull, and with humble thoughts,
And Prayers reward your piety, deſpife not
The offer of it here; you have not caſt
Your bounty on a Rock, while the ſeeds thrive
Where you did place your Charity; my joy
May ſeem ill dreſt to come like ſorrow thus,
But you may ſee through every tear, and find
My eyes meant Innocence, and your hearty welcome.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Who did prepare thee Feliſarda thus
To entertain me weeping? ſure our ſoules
Meet and converſe, and we not know't; there is
Such beauty in that watry circle, I
Am fearfull to come neer, and breath a kiſs
Upon thy cheek, leſt I pollute that Criſtall,
And yet I muſt ſalute thee, and I dare
With one warm ſigh meet, and dry up this ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: I ſhall forget all miſery; for when
I look upon the World, and race of men,
I find 'em proud, and all ſo unacquainted
With pitty to ſuch miſerable things
As poverty hath made us, that I muſt
Conclude you ſent from Heaven.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh do not Flatter
Thy ſelf poor Feliſarda; I'm Mortall,
The life I bear about me is not mine,
But borrow'd to come to thee once again,
And ere I go, to clear how much I love thee—
But firſt I have a ſtory to deliver,
A tale will make thee ſad, but I muſt tell it,
There is one dead that lov'd thee not.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: One dead
That lov'd not me? this carries fir in nature
No killing ſound; I ſhall be ſad to know
I did deſerve an Enemy, or he want
A Charity at death.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy cruell Enemy,
And my beſt friend, hath took Eternall leave
And's gone, to heaven I hope, excuſe my tears,
It is a tribute I muſt pay his memory,
For I did love my Father.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Ha! your Father?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes Feliſarda, he is gone, that in
The morning promis'd many years, but death
Hath in few hours made him as ſtiff, as all
The winds, and winter, had thrown cold upon him,
And wiſper'd him to marble.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Now truſt me,
My heart weepes for him, but I underſtand
Not hovv I vvas concern'd in his diſpleaſure;
And in ſuch height as you profeſs.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He did
Command me on his bleſſing to forſake thee;
Was't not a cruell precept, to inforce
The ſoul, and curſe his Son for honeſt love?

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: This is a wound indeed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But not ſo mortall;
For his laſt breath was Balſom pour'd upon it,
By which he did reverſe his malediction;
And I that groan'd beneath the weight of that
Anathema, ſunk almoſt to deſpair,
Where night and heavy ſhades hung round about me,
Found my ſelf riſing like the morning Star
To view the World.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Never I hope to be
Eclips'd agen.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This was a welcom bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Heaven had a care of both; my joyes are mighty.
Vouchſafe me ſir your pardon if I bluſh
And ſay I love, but rather than the peace
That ſhould preſerve your boſom, ſuffer for
My ſake, 'twere better I were dead.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, live.
And live for ever happy, thou deſerved'ſt it.
It is Fernando doth make haſt to ſleep
In his forgotten duſt.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Thoſe accents did
Not ſound ſo cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: doſt love me?

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Do not, I prethee do not, I am loſt,
Alas I am no more Fernando, there
Is nothing but the Empty name of him
That did betray thee, place a guard about
Thy heart be time, I am not worth this ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Did not Fernando ſpeak all this? alas
He knew that I was poor before, and needed not
Deſpiſe me now for that.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Deſert me goodneſs
When I upbraid thy wants. 'Tis I am poor,
For I ha' not a ſtock in all the World
Of ſo much duſt, as would contrive one narrow
Cabin to ſhroud a worm; my dying Father
Hath given away my Birthright to Franciſco,
I'm diſinherited, thrown out of all,
But the ſmall Earth I borrow, thus to walk on;
And having nothing left, I come to kiſs thee,
And take my everlaſting leave of thee too.
Farewell, this will perſwade thee to conſent
To my Eternall abſence.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: I muſt beſeech you ſtay a little ſir,
And clear my faith. Hath your diſpleaſed Father
Depriv'd you then of all, and made Franciſco
The Lord of your Inheritance, without hope
To be repair'd in Fortune?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis ſad truth.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: This is a happineſs I did not look for.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A happineſs?

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Yes Sir, a happineſs.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Can Feliſarda take delight to hear
What hath undone her ſervant?

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: Heaven avert it.
But 'tis not worth my grief to be aſſur'd
That this will bring me nearer now to him
Whom I moſt honor of the World; and tis
My pride, if you exceed me not in Fortune,
That I can boaſt my heart, as high, and rich,
With noble flame, and every way your equall,
And if you be as poor as I Fernando,
I can deſerve you now, and love you more
Than when your expectation carried all
The pride and bloſſoms of the ſpring upon it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thoſe ſhadowes will not feed more than our fancies;
Two poverties will keep but a thin table;
And while wee dream of this high nouriſhment,
Wee do but ſtarve more gloriouſly.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: 'Tis eaſe.
And wealth firſt taught us art to ſurfet by;
Nature is wiſe, not coſtly, and will ſpread
A table for us in the Wilderneſs;
And the kind Earth keep us alive, and healthfull,
With what her boſom doth invite us to;
The brooks, not there ſuſpected as the Wine
That ſomtime Princes quaff, are all tranſparent,
And with their pretty murmurs call to taſt 'em.
In every tree a Choriſter to ſing
Health to our loves, our lives ſhall there be free
As the firſt knowledge was from ſin, and all
Our dreams as Innocent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh Feliſarda?
If thou didſt own leſs Virtue, I might prove
Unkind and marry thee, but being ſo rich
In goodneſs, it becomes me not to bring
One that is poor, in every vvorth, to vvaſt
So excellent a Dower, be free, and meet
One that hath Wealth to cheriſh it, I ſhall
Undo thee quite, but pray for me, as I,
That thou maiſt change for a more happy Bridgroom;
I dare as ſoon be guilty of my death,
As make thee miſerable by expecting me.
Farwell, and do not wrong my ſoul, to think
That any ſtorm could ſeparate us two,
But that I have no fortune now to ſerve thee.

sp.speaker: Feliſ.
sp.l: This will be no exception ſir, I hope,
When wee are both dead, yet our bodies may
Be cold, and ſtrangers in the Winding ſheet;
We ſhall be married when our ſpirits meets.

div.head: Act V.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Your daughter does not uſe me well Don Carlos.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I know not what to think,
Some great misfortune muſt be the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Not yet appear? they might,
And they had crept like Tortoyſes, Ariv'd
Before this time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: There is ſome ſtrange diſaſter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Coach orethrown, and both their lives
Endanger'd, can but excuſe'm.
Oh my Lord, Don Carlos.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Tragick voice of women ſtricks mine eare.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where is our Daughter?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: My fear almoſt diſtracts me, ſhe is gone,
Stoln, raviſh'd from me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Alſt.
sp.l: An armed Troop
In Viſards forc'd her from my coach; and heaven
Knows where they have hurried the poor Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A troop of armed Devils.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Let them be
A legion, they are all damn'd.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Nay they were men and mortall ſure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I w'on'ot leave one ſoul amongſt them all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mine is in torment.
I'th'hope & height of my ambition
To be thus cros'd! how ſcap'd you?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Alas I was not young enough, I offer'd
My ſelf to bear her company, and ſuffer
As much as ſhe did, but one boyſterous fellow
With a ſtarch'd voice, and a worſe vizard, took me
Juſt here above my Sciatica, and quoited me
Into the coach • gen upon my head,
I had alarum in't for half an hour,
And ſo I ſcap'd with life.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Did they uſe her with any rigor?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: To ſay truth they were gentle enough to her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: That mollifies. and they may live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hell overtake 'em, lets return, they had better
Committed inceſt, than this rape.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They had better raviſh'd Proſerpine before
Don Lucifer's own face. I am all fury.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Pardon my de • r Jacinta, It was love
That threw me on this act, I had no patience
To ſee thee forc'd into a mariage
By a covetous Father, whoſe devotion
Is only Wealth and Title; I eſteem
No danger, if at laſt the fair Jacinta
Smile and allow this duty; let not ſilence
Deprive me longer of thy voice, whoſe every
Accent will pleaſe, though it pronounce my ſentence;
There's death in this Eclipſs too, ſweet diſmiſs
Thy ungentle veil, and let thy eyes make bright
This melancholy air, that droops and dies
For want of thy reſtoring beams.

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: Now ſir,
What think you of your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are the Lady Eſtefania I take it.

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: Yes, you did take me from the coach
But by a conſequence I find, you thought
Jacinta in your power, I could have told you,
Had you diſcover'd ſooner what you were,
Where to have found your Miſtris, but ſhee's now
Above your hope, and by the prieſt ere this
Made wife to Don Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To Don Pedro?

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: It was not fir impoſſible that I
(Had not your violence prevented me)
(By a plot between Jacinta and my ſelf,
To take her place and perſon in the coach)
Had by this time been married to Count Pedro,
Whom I have povver and Juſtice ſir to challenge
If Contracts carry weight.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Have I ſo long
Ly'n beating at the buſh, and is the bird
Fled to Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: I ſhould ſhew I had
A paſſion ſir, and ſenſe of this captivity,
But that I find 'twas error, and not will
Lead you to this; and your own loſs now made
Irreparable, helpes to tye up my anger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, I muſt confeſs a wrong, and dare
Submit to let your anger puniſh me,
For I deſpiſe my ſelf, now I have loſt
My expectation, and if you pleaſe
To think I had no malice in this act
To you, You can propoſe no ſatisfaction
I ſhall eſteem a penance to repair you,
As far as my poor life, if you'l direct it.

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly promis'd ſir. You ſhall redeem
In my thoughts what is paſt, if you be pleas'd
To make my ſtay no longer here; I have
No deſperate aim to make Don Pedro yet
Know how to right me, or make publick what
Should bind his honor to perform.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Was not Luys Madam entertain'd your Servant?

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: I ſhall make known the ſtory if you walk
But to Don Carlos Houſe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You ſhall command me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No newes yet of Jacinta?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He muſt
Not live in Spain, nor in the World, if my
Revenge can overtake him, that has ſtoln
My Daughter; could you not by voice or habit
Gueſs at the raviſher? Ye are traitors all.

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Now I conſider better, I ſuſpect
Alberto one of the conſpiracie,
Some voice did ſound like his. You know he lov'd her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha! Alberto?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: And how he might engage ſome Ruffians
To croſs Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: 'Twas he, where's Luys?
I do not like his abſence, thei'r both guilty;
My own blood turnd a rebell? ſend for the Alcaides,
They ſhall both trot like theeves to the Corrigidor.
Where is Count Pedro?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Gon in ſearch of his loſt Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: When all things were ripe,
The very Prieſt prepar'd to ſeal our Ioyes,
A work my brain did labour for, and ſweat
With hope to ſee accompliſh'd, undermin'd?
And in a Minute all blown up?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Have patience
She may be found agen.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But how my Lord
May be inclin'd to accept her foil'd, or wounded
In fame—

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Luys is here.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Borachio, here's a ſpectacle! more affliction?
Where is your Siſter, whats become of Jacinta?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Siſter and Jacinta are gone together.
I know all the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: She is very well, I know not where ſhe is.
But Don Alberto is an honeſt Gentleman,
And has by this time done the feat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Confuſion—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You think you had all the wit, it was my plot.
You may thank heaven that you are old, and ugly,
You had been no Mother of this World. But ſir,
I have ſome newes would be deliver'd privately.
Mother of mine, avant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Th'art not my Son.
Was ever man ſo miſerable? away
Thou ſpunge; get him to ſleeep,

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: I dare not medle with him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In ſobriety a word. Car. Where is Alberto?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Where every honeſt man ſhould be abed, with 〈◊〉 ,
Old man, I ha'conſider'd o'the former mater we talk'd on
And would do things like a dutiful ſon, but I find that a
Wife is not altogether ſo convenient for me as a—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Will none deliver me?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: They are ſomewhat ſlug,
Now I have found out an excellent tumbler,
sp.p: That can do the Somerſet, pleaſe you to be acquainted with her, and give me your opinion, She ſhall play with all the ſtews in Chriſtendome, for all you are worth, if I live, and yet ſhe is but 17 there's a periwinkle, I had a Gemini, before I went to travell, And I am bound in conſcience, if you think fit, to ſee her well Provided for—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: With whips, i'l have her skin flead off.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Her skin fled off? doſt thou know mortal man
What thou haſt ſaid? I tel the Don, nothing can come neer
Her in the ſhape of an Officer, ſhe is a very Baſilisk & wil
Kill em with her eyes 3 ſcore yards point blank, but you
May talk, & do your pleaſure with her, for I came a
Purpoſe to bring her to your lodging, if you love me,
Do but ſee her, it ſhall coſt you nothing, you ſhall
Be my friend, hang money?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thus will my ſtate conſume, vexation!
What ſhall I do? when you have ſlept Luys
I'l tell you more, attend him to his Chamber
And make his Door faſt.

sp.speaker: Luys
sp.l: You vvill conſider on't, upon thoſe terms, I vvil go
Sleep at vvinckling.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And vvo'not all this take a vvay my ſenſes?
My Son is loft too, this is all a curſe
For my ambition and my Avarice.

div.stage: Enter Alſimra and a ſervant with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Alſ.
sp.l: Nevvs Don Carlos from our Daughter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha, a Letteri 'tis Iacintas hand.

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Knovv'ſt vvhere ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes Madam, and her reſolution
• o attend her Father, with my Maſter Don Pranciſco
• f Don Carlos pleaſe to admit 'em, the matters done.

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: What matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are as faſt as any Prieſt can make em.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wife to Franciſco, now his Fathers heir?
That's ſome allay, if it be true, ſhe writes,
Don Pedro was contracted to Eſtefania, who ſupplied
Her perſon in the Coach—twas not Jacinta was raviſh'd
Then, Don Pedro was not noble, after he had made faith,
To intangle my Iacinta. Hum, ſay they ſhall
Be welcome. Ser. They are preſent fir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am nor yet collected, but'if this
Paper be juſtified, I receive you both.
Peruſe thoſe wonders Alſimira.

sp.speaker: Iacin.
sp.l: Sir, though by the tye of nature you may challenge
All duty, this is done ſo like a Father
It exceeds all your care.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let this confirme,
I bring a fortune not to be deſpis'd,
But were I Maſter of the World, I ſhould
At price of all my wealth, thiuk this a treaſure
Purchac'd too cheap.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My bleſſing and my prayers, I'm new created,
And bow to that great providence; all Joy
Spread through your ſoules; this is not much amiſs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But what's become of Madam Eſtefania
That took Iacintas place?

sp.speaker: Alſi.
sp.l: Forc'd from the Coach
By Don Alberto, thinking her my Daughter

sp.speaker: Iacin.
sp.l: That part of our plot fail'd, but my intents
Were fair, and to aſſiſt this injur'd Ladie

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Don Pedro ſir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You ſhall for ſome few minutes.
Withdraw into that Chamber, in his paſſion
He may be violent, leave me to moderate.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ſhall obey you fir.

sp.speaker: Fed.
sp.l: Was ever man of my great birth and fortune
Affronted thus? I am become the talk
Of every Picaro and Ladron, I challenge
A reparation of my honor; where's
Jacinta? tis a plot, a bace contrivement
To make my name ridiculous, the ſubject
Of every ſcurrill language.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord with pardon
Of your Alteſa, y'are not Injur'd here,
Unleſs I have been faulty in too much
Obſervance, and deſires to ſerve your perſon,
VVith almoſt ſacrifice of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha! too much to me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I would you had remembred
How much your Honor was engag'd before,
By Contract to another, when you mock'd
The Innocent Jacinta, now not mine.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: VVho hath traduc'd my fame, or mention'd me
VVith that diſhonour? I diſclaim all Contracts.
The unconfin'd Aire's not more free, than I
To all the World, except your beauteous Daughter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do you know the Lady Eſtefania?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Dares ſhe make ſaucie claim? my breath diſſolves it
If every Lady whom we grace with our
Converſe ſhould, challenge men of my Nobility—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I wiſh my Lord you could evade it, for
The honor of my Family; if your conſcience
Or Art can nullifie that Ladies sintereſt
I am reſolv'd—my Son Luys ſhall Aſide.
Then marry With that Widdow, I have no other
Ambition.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You are wiſe, and I
Am fortified to clear my ſelf thought-free
sp.stage: Enter Alberto, Fſtefania with a Letter.
sp.l: From any promiſe to that ſullen Madam.
Ha! tis Jacinta, and ſhe wears the Jewell
I did preſent, conſpicuouſly; I ask
No reaſor for thy abſence, let me chain
My darling in this amorous curl, tis happineſs
Enough to repoſſeſs thee, not the policie
And power of Hell ſhall ſeparate us agen.

sp.speaker: Fſte.
sp.l: It is but Juſtice ſir. Ped. Ha! Eſtefania.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do you know her ſir?

sp.speaker: Eſte.
sp.l: Do you know this character? Ped. Conſpiracy.

sp.speaker: Eſt.
sp.l: When this is read Don Carlos
You will imagine he has wrong'd your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Is this your hand Count Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Mine—tis counterfeit
Upon my honor, and I thus diſſolve
Thy inſolent claim.

sp.speaker: Eſte.
sp.l: Nothing can bind I ſee
A falſe heart

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This muſt give you freedom Madam,
If you releaſe his haſty vow.

sp.speaker: Eſte.
sp.l: Faith cannot
Be compeld ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Theſe are all Impoſtures;
I take my ſelf into my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What ſhall become of her my noble Count?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I pitty her
But cannot cure her wound, and if you be
Her friend, adviſe her to contain her paſſions,
And wiſely love one that can entertain it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You hear this Madam?

sp.speaker: Eſte.
sp.l: And can ſmile upon
His viol ated fath.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now for Luys,
To ſtrike in with the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Hae's a ſleep.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ile wake and quicken him.
Hadſt thou bin worth my love, I ſhould have held
Thee worth my anger ſhadow, of a Lord.
Thy greatneſs I deſpiſe, and think thee now
Too poor for my revenge, and freely give
Thee back thy barren promiſes, and when
I read in ſtory, one that has been perjur'd,
I'l write Don Pearo in the place of him
That brok his faith, and thank my fate t' have miſt thee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: If you pleaſe Madam, while he is i'th' humor
Of being baſe, I'l make him gather up
Theſe paper reliques, which he ſhall make him ſelf
Up into rolls, and having ſwallowed 'em
For Pills, thank you, his Phyſick was ſo gentle.

sp.speaker: Eſte.
sp.l: It will be too much time & breath loſt on him.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: It will become me Madam to attend you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: So, ſhe is taken off' and my path free
To Carlos Daughter.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: Contracted to Don Pedro? ſay.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: She was, where is Eſtefania?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Gone with Alberto; proud to wait upon
The Lady I neglected.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Follow 'em Luys?
I do not like he ſhould inſinuate
Now ſhe is free, and his hopes deſperat in
Jacintas love. Luys How long have I ſlept ſir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou doſt dream ſtill, perſue the Widdow now
Or never look at ſuch a fortune.

sp.speaker: Luys
sp.l: Is ſhe gone with Alberto? what if I ſay,
I have lain with her, and that ſhee's with child by me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That would ſtain both your fames; away and welcom
When thou return'ſt, and ſhe confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Luys
sp.l: Ile confirm her, or confound ſomebody,
No more, I am awake, this is Don Pedro
I'l talk with him firſt, vvill you juſtefie,
The Widdovv is a Widdovv ſtill, and ſweet
For all your Contract, that you have not been
My rivall as they ſay after the fleſh,
And that you did not knovv I had a mind,
Or not a mind, to do the deed of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Not I upon my honor.

sp.speaker: Luys
sp.l: You are vvitneſs—novv to Alberte.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Manage the bufineſs temperatly.

sp.speaker: Luys
sp.l: Let me alone to be temperate, if I do not coſen
Some body, let me never drink Sack agen.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What think you of Jacinta novv my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As on the Saint I pay my chief devotions.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I come to ſeek one, that I late call'd Brother,
But he hath forfeted that Name, and Juſtice
Weary of ſuch a prodigy in nature
Hath arm'd me thus in her revenge, Don Carlos,
Obſcure him not, no darkneſs can protect him,
My ſvvord ſhall forrage every room like lightning,
No Cave but it ſhall viſit, and through ribs
Of ſteel compell my paſſage to his heart,
Although I meet him in his Miſtr is Armes,
The lovers Sanctuary, I dare force Franciſco,
And vvith my Svvord cut the Embrace that chains him,
Rather then he ſhall glory in my ruines,
And revell out, thoſe honors, vvith her, he
Took from my blood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It ſhall not need Fernando.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Hum, here is like to be a bloody buſineſs,
I'l not diſturb 'em.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As you are Brothers, by your Fathers duſt
That ſhould ſleep quiet in his Urne, by her
Dear name that gave you life, that novv prayes for you,
Chide this unnaturall furie.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: VVhat demands Fernando?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My inheritance wrought from me
By thy ſlie creeping to ſupplant my birth,
And cheat our Fathers eaſie ſoul, unvvorthily
Betraying to his anger for thy luſt
Of wealth, the love and promiſe of two hearts,
Poor Feliſarda and Fernando now
Wither at ſoul, and rob'd by thee of that
Should cheriſh virtue, like to rifled Pilgrims
Met on the way, and having told their ſtory,
And drop'd their even teares for both their loſs,
Wander from one another.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tis not ſure

sp.speaker: Fernando,
sp.l: but his paſion (that obeys not
The counſel of his reaſon) would accuſe me,
And if my Father now, ſince ſpirits loſe not
Intelligence, but more active when they have
Shook off their chains of fleſh, would leave his dwelling,
And viſit this courſe orbe agen: my Innocence
Should dare the appeal, and make Fernando ſee
His empty accuſations.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He that thrives
By wicked art, has confidence to dreſs
His action with ſimplicity, and ſhapes
To cheat our credulous natures, tis my wonder
Thou durſt do ſo much injury Franciſco
As muſt provoke my Juſtice, to revenge,
Yet wear no Sword.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I need no guard, I know
Thou darſt not kill me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Dare I not?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And name thy cauſe, tis thy ſuſpition not Franciſo
Hath wrought thee high and paſſionate, to aſſure it,
If you dare violate, I dare poſſeſs you
Wit hall my title to your Land.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How is that?
Will you reſign the intereſt to ſuch
A fair Eſtate, and wrong my Daughter ſir?

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: Let him receive it at his perill.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It was my Fathers act, not mine, he trembled
To hear his curſe alive, what horror will
His conſcience feel, when he ſhall ſpurn his duſt,
And call the reverend ſhade from his bleſt ſeat,
To this bad World again, to walk and fright him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am abus'd

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Can this be more than dream?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir you may cancell it, but think withall
How you can anſwer him that's dead, when he
Shall charge your timorous ſoul for this contempt
To nature and Religion, to break
His laſt bequeſt, and breath, that ſeal'd your bleſſings?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Theſe are fine fancies.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here, and may it proſper,
Where my good Father meant it, I'm orecome.
Forgive me, and enjoy it, I may find
Some Earth that is not thine, where I may dy
And take up a dark Chamber, love Jacinta,
And while I ſeek out where to be forgotten
Live happy, and devide the ſpring between you,

div.stage: Enter Ramires, Feliſarda, and Teodoro, aloof.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So, ſo, all's well agen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Fernando ſtay.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha, my Father and Feliſarda?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Don Ramyres and my Neece?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are they both dead?
I dare kneel too, they do converſe. Don Carlos
Do not you know that ſhape? 'tis wondrous like
Your Neece.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And that your Father, ha!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How long hath Feliſarda been a ſad
Companion to the ſhades? I did not think
To find thee in this pale ſociety,
Of ghoſts ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Feliſar.
sp.l: I am alive Fernando,
And Don Ramires ſtill, thy living Father.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may believe it ſir, I was o'th' counſell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is a joy will tempt me, wiſh to live
Here, without more ambition to change
For bleſſings of the other World; and is
My Father willing that wee both ſhould live?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Men thought you dead.

sp.speaker: Ramir.
sp.l: It lay within the knowledge of Franciſco and ſome few
By this device to advance my younger Son
To a Mariage with Jacinta ſir, and try
Fernando's Piety and his Miſtris Vertue,
Which I have found worth him, and my acceptance,
With her I give thee what thy birth did challenge.
Receive thy Feliſarda.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis a joy,
So flowing, it drowns all my faculties,
My ſoul will not contain I fear, but loſe
And leave me in this extaſie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am cheated.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Not ſo, what dower you add above that fortune,
Deſcends upon her by your Siſters Legacie
Franciſco ſhall deſerve, with a proportion
Out of my ſtate; live, and be happy both,
You ſhall not want a Father in my care.
Our children thus increas'd Don Carlos, 'tis
Our ſhame if we neglect 'em; Teodore
You now may call me Brother.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: I'm honor'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well, take my bleſſing too, love her Franciſco.
My bounty is to come, and if my Son
But finiſh with his Miſtris—hee's return'd,
Where is the Widdow?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sure enough.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And Don Alberto.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I ha made him ſure too, I ha pepper'd him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In your ear, I ha cut his throat, do none perſue

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I hope thou haſt not kil'd him? ha!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You hope to late, I could not help it, you ſaid
He was my Rivall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not to loud.

sp.speaker: Lù.
sp.l: Where, where ſhall I obſcure me, the Alcaides
Will be here preſently, and ſearch for me.
I left him giving up the ghoſt, at a cranny
I made into his ſide, through which a man
Might ſee into his midriff.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Art thou deſperate?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Beſide one window that did look into his lungs,
From whence his wind came ſtrong enough,
In ſix hours ſail to diſpatch a Carrack to the ſtraightes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'm mad.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I ſhould neglect my life, but 'twould not ſound well
With your honor that Don Carlos Son was hang'd,
Or put into the Gallies; are they not come yet?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am undone, there is no ſafety here,
Make faſt thoſe doors, and by the Poſtern gate
Thou maiſt eſcape, take the beſt Horſe, away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I ſhall want money ſir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Come follow me?
This accident I fear will quite diſtract me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You muſt diſpatch me quickly ſir, there is
No ſtaying to tell the money, gee't me in lump,
I'l count it afterwards, good ſir make haſt.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Something hath hapned that doth freſh
Perplex him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Where is Don Pedro?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hee's here.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The ſtorm is over ſure, I hear no noiſe,
Toledos are aſleep, Jacinta? have
I found my love?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here 'twas loſt indeed,
I muſt allow no ſuch Familiarity
With my Wife.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How? married?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You have not us'd me thus?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It had been Impious to divorce your heart
From Eſtefania; My good Lord, wee know
Your Lordſhip is religious in your promiſes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I defy all Eſtefanias, Lady you are civill.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It will become my care ſo to preſerve her
My Honorable Count.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Honorable?
It appeares not by theſe contempts.

sp.speaker: Ramyr.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip cannot want a Female Furniture.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I muſt have ſome body now I'm prepar'd, my blood
Will take itill, would I had Eſtefaenia;
Shee's here, Madam I hope you have
A better faith than to believe I was in Earneſt,
Don Pedro is only at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Eſte.
sp.l: 'Tis too late ſir, this Gent. is witneſs,
Of your ſurrender, and is now poſſeſt
Of all that's mine.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: It was your Noble bounty,
For which I cannot ſtudy a return
More apt than to reſign to your good Lordſhip,
My Intereſt in Jacinta, give you joy Count.
Such a rich Widdow ſerves my turn.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: So ſo,
If I conſider well this is but Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha, are not you Don Alberto: fetch back Luys.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The very ſame ſir, and this Lady is my Wife,
Pleaſe you ſalute her.

sp.speaker: Luys
sp.l: Sir for the credit of your wiſdom talk not,
The man you ſee's alive and married too,
With my conſent, alas I ow'd him mony,
That Widdow has paid all, I muſt be honeſt,
I had no heart to leave you ſo unſatisfied,
Theſe ſums muſt go for other debts,
My debts do clog my conſcience, and are better
W 〈…〉 are timely paid ſir, then let run
With their • o • g Teeth to bite your ſtate hereafter,
A 〈…〉 when I am free you dare but truſt me—
Was ever Father cheated thus, come hither,
H 〈…〉 thou be ſo impudent?
〈…〉 cannot help it ſir, unleſs you dye
〈…〉 me better means, I ſhall make bold
〈…〉 devices, you are my Father ſir,
〈…〉 bound—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To coſen me?
All muſt be mine, and if
〈…〉 ſelf a little before the day,
〈…〉 be no loſer when you come to reckon,

〈◊〉
• ha'not make a breach twixt you and I,
They are honeſt men I ow this money too,
When I am cleer preſcribe me any method
And rank me like your ſon, I will deſerve
Y … ſhall forget my wildneſs, and acknowledge me
A convert without blemiſh to your family.
I muſt be Interceſſor.
And we all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'l think upon't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Since I cannot have Jacinta, I deſire
I may have her Brother.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Not in marriage.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I like his wit, his ſpirit, and his humor,
D • not you love a wench?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Thou ſha't never want.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Wenches?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Wee'l live together, and if thy Father
Be n • t bountifull, thou ſhalt command my fortune.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You ſpeak nobly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ladies, I ask your pardon
Unleſs you hold me deſperate, diſdaine not
That I may this day wait upon your triumph,
And to each Bride offer ſome guift to expiate
My folly and offence.

sp.speaker: Rami.
sp.l: You are too bountifull.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Y'are all my gueſts to day.

sp.speaker: Rami.
sp.l: I beg your next
Remove may place the Scen of Joy with me,
My houſe ſhall be much honor'd, lead the way
With Verſe and Wine let Poets crown this day.

l.hi: SO ſo, your dangers over, and the ſtate
Secure, as when our Fleet in Eighty Eight
Was fir'd and ſcatter'd, to confirm it true

lg.l: Here is Don Pedro taken Priſoner too,

l.hi: I'm at your mercy Gentlemen, and I
So far as my poor part i'th' Play comes too,
But I am innocent from hurt to you,
And I dare quit the reſt from any plot
Meant but to pleaſe, if you believe it not
I dare make oath, your hands can do no leſs
Than certifie your friends what I confeſs.
